title: Can you transplant a head to another body? - Max G. Levy

multiple-choice.question: Who performed the first monkey head transplant in 1970?

options.label: A
options.text: Dr. Robert White's team

options.label: B
options.text: Dr. White alone

options.label: C
options.text: A team of neurosurgeons from the NIH

options.label: D
options.text: A team of scientists from a private research institution

multiple-choice.question: What was the main goal of Dr. White's head transplant surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: To cure cancer

options.label: B
options.text: To replace a patient's organs at once

options.label: C
options.text: To connect the head of one monkey to the body of another

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of anesthesia on animals

multiple-choice.question: What was the main challenge in reconnecting the severed spinal cord in Dr. White's surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: The high energy demands of the brain

options.label: B
options.text: The difficulty in reconnecting the blood vessels

options.label: C
options.text: The guaranteed paralysis of the patient

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of immune rejection

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of brain cooling in neurosurgery?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the risk of complications

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the outcome of surgery

options.label: C
options.text: It allows surgeons to operate for longer periods without causing damage

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in emergency situations

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the ethical concerns surrounding Dr. White's research raises?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of animals in research

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of immune rejection

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for debilitating pain and neurological damage

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the monkey's ability to see, smell, and hear after the surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: It proves that the operation was successful

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that the monkey is in pain

options.label: C
options.text: It indicates that the brain is still functioning

options.label: D
options.text: It has no significance

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the brain and the body?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain is separate from the body

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is connected to the body through circuits and signaling systems

options.label: C
options.text: The brain is a part of the body

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is a separate entity from the body

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the debate about the mind-body divide?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no significance in modern neuroscience

options.label: B
options.text: It is only relevant to philosophers

options.label: C
options.text: It raises questions about the nature of consciousness and the self

options.label: D
options.text: It is only relevant to the field of neurosurgery

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in performing a human head transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: The technical difficulty of reconnecting the blood vessels

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of immune rejection

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for debilitating pain and neurological damage

options.label: D
options.text: The question of who would emerge as the dominant individual

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Dr. White's research in the context of bioethics?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no significance

options.label: B
options.text: It raises questions about the use of animals in research

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the importance of considering the potential consequences of scientific research

options.label: D
options.text: It is only relevant to the field of neurosurgery

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Fan

options.label: D
options.text: Coils

options.label: C
options.text: They pick up heat from outside and move it into the house.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It has 10,000 times the global warming impact of CO2.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By using heat from seas, sewage, and data centers.

options.label: D
options.text: By using heat from underground.

options.label: A
options.text: Because they produce more heat than the energy put into them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they use electricity to make heat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they get the extra energy for free from heat in the air or underground.

options.label: D

title: Why don't "tough" and "dough" rhyme? - Arika Okrent

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the complexity of English spelling conventions?

options.label: A
options.text: The English language is inherently irregular.

options.label: B
options.text: The influence of French and Latin on English spelling.

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of standardization in English spelling.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of the printing press on English spelling.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the origin of the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: It arose from old Germanic tribes that invaded the British Isles over 1,500 years ago.

options.label: B
options.text: It was introduced by Roman missionaries in the 6th century CE.

options.label: C
options.text: It was influenced by French speakers after the Norman invasion of 1066.

options.label: D
options.text: It was developed by the church and formal education.

options.label: C
options.text: It promoted the use of Latin alphabet for English words.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The English Vowel Change.

options.label: D
options.text: The Latin Influence.

multiple-choice.question: How did the Great Vowel Shift affect the word "tough"?

options.label: A
options.text: It changed the pronunciation of the "t" sound.

options.label: B
options.text: It changed the pronunciation of the "o" sound.

options.label: C
options.text: It changed the pronunciation of the "u" sound.

options.label: D
options.text: It changed the pronunciation of the "g" sound.

options.label: A
options.text: "house"

options.label: B
options.text: "boat"

options.label: C
options.text: "tough"

options.label: D
options.text: "dough"

options.label: A
options.text: The complexity of English spelling conventions.

options.label: B
options.text: The irregularity of English pronunciation.

options.label: C
options.text: The influence of French and Latin on English vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of standardization in English grammar.

multiple-choice.question: How did the Norman invasion of 1066 affect the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: It introduced French as the dominant language.

options.label: B
options.text: It eliminated the use of Latin in English.

options.label: C
options.text: It promoted the use of Germanic runes for English words.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the English language.

options.label: A
options.text: "dough"

options.label: B
options.text: "tough"

options.label: C
options.text: "enough"

options.label: D
options.text: "women"

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one reason why the English language has many irregularities?

options.label: A
options.text: The influence of French and Latin on English vocabulary.

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of standardization in English spelling.

options.label: C
options.text: The history of the English language, including the impact of various invasions and cultural influences.

options.label: D
options.text: The development of the English language through the church and formal education.

options.label: C
options.text: It will lead to more people using the service

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: What happened when these 6 dictators took over? - Stephanie Honchell Smith

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**

options.label: A
options.text: The ancient Roman statesman Cincinnatus was known for his ability to lead the Roman army to victory against the Aequi.

options.label: B
options.text: Cincinnatus was chosen to serve as dictator of Rome due to his military prowess.

options.label: C
options.text: Cincinnatus was plowing his fields when news arrived that the Aequi had invaded Rome.

options.label: D
options.text: Cincinnatus was a powerful enemy of Rome.

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**

options.label: A
options.text: The myth of the "benevolent dictator" is the idea of a leader who holds absolute power and uses it for the common good.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea of a dictator can be appealing when a democracy is functioning properly.

options.label: C
options.text: A dictatorship is a system of government where power is held by a single individual who is free to impose their vision on society.

options.label: D
options.text: A benevolent dictator is someone who is willing to give up power and return to their normal life.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**

options.label: A
options.text: A modern democracy is a system of government where a single individual holds absolute power.

options.label: B
options.text: In a dictatorship, the leader is accountable to the people and is limited by the law.

options.label: C
options.text: A benevolent dictator is a leader who holds absolute power but uses it for the common good and is willing to give it up after a certain period.

options.label: D
options.text: In a dictatorship, the leader is not accountable to anyone and is free to impose their vision on society.

options.label: A

title: Scientists are obsessed with this lake - Nicola Storelli and Daniele Zanzi

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the powerful, poisonous, world-changing gas that was produced by microorganisms roughly 3 billion years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrogen

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon Dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: Sulfur Dioxide

options.label: A
options.text: It's located in a tropical region

options.label: B
options.text: It's a meromictic lake with two distinct bodies of water

options.label: C
options.text: It's the largest lake in the world

options.label: D
options.text: It's completely frozen year-round

options.text: Granite

options.label: B
options.text: Dolomite

options.label: C
options.text: Sulfur

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Anaerobic bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: Photosynthetic bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: Decomposer bacteria

options.label: A
options.text: Chromatium okenii

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: Sulfur bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrogen bacteria

multiple-choice.question: How do the microorganisms in the bottom layer of Lake Cadagno get their energy?

options.label: A
options.text: By consuming oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: By consuming sulfur

options.label: C
options.text: By photosynthesis

options.label: D
options.text: By decomposing organic matter

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique relationship between the photosynthesizing bacteria and the zooplankton in Lake Cadagno?

options.label: A
options.text: The bacteria produce a toxin that kills the zooplankton

options.label: B
options.text: The zooplankton eat the bacteria and use them as a food source

options.label: C
options.text: The bacteria and zooplankton have a mutualistic relationship

options.label: D
options.text: The bacteria and zooplankton have a commensal relationship

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the bioconvection phenomenon in Lake Cadagno?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a sign of the lake's pollution

options.label: B
options.text: It's a sign of the lake's eutrophication

options.label: C
options.text: It might be a clue to how early life evolved the ability to swim

options.label: D
options.text: It's a sign of the lake's thermal stratification

multiple-choice.question: Why is Lake Cadagno an important site for scientists to study?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a tropical lake

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a meromictic lake with two distinct bodies of water

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a lake with a unique anoxic ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a lake with a diverse fish population

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of studying Lake Cadagno's anoxic ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows scientists to model the world before the Great Oxygen Catastrophe

options.label: B
options.text: It allows scientists to study the effects of pollution on the lake

options.label: C
options.text: It allows scientists to study the effects of eutrophication on the lake

options.label: D
options.text: It allows scientists to study the effects of thermal stratification on the lake

options.text: Whether the Axiom of Choice is sufficient for mathematics

title: How to protect the oceans - Sylvia Earle

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the ocean's big fish have been killed in the speaker's lifetime?
According to the speaker, what percentage of the Earth's water is ocean?
What is the speaker's wish for the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To support a global network of marine protected areas

options.label: B
options.text: To explore the ocean using Google Earth

options.label: C
options.text: To learn about the life support system

options.label: D
options.text: To engage in climate change mitigation

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the speaker's "big wish"?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect 10% of the ocean

options.label: B
options.text: To explore the deep sea

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a global network of marine protected areas

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce carbon emissions

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the 1872 establishment of Yellowstone National Park?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of marine protected areas

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first national park in the world

options.label: C
options.text: It set a precedent for protecting natural systems on land

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on environmental conservation

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between the ocean and the Earth's climate?

options.label: A
options.text: The ocean drives climate and weather

options.label: B
options.text: The ocean is affected by climate change

options.label: C
options.text: The ocean has no impact on climate

options.label: D
options.text: The ocean is a separate entity from the climate

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the current state of the ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: It is pristine and untouched

options.label: B
options.text: It is in good shape, with only minor issues

options.label: C
options.text: It is facing significant threats, including overfishing and pollution

options.label: D
options.text: It is not important for human life

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the global plan of action mentioned by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce carbon emissions

options.label: B
options.text: To protect biodiversity and mitigate climate change impacts

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the deep sea

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a global network of marine protected areas

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of the high seas?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the largest, most protected ecosystem on Earth

options.label: B
options.text: They are the largest, least protected ecosystem on Earth

options.label: C
options.text: They have no impact on the ocean's health

options.label: D
options.text: They are not important for marine life

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To take action now to protect the ocean

options.label: B
options.text: To wait and see what happens in the future

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on other environmental issues

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the ocean's problems

title: Picture a perfect society. What does it look like? - Joseph Lacey

multiple-choice.question: Who is the political philosopher credited with developing the thought experiment known as "the original position"?

options.label: A
options.text: John Locke

options.label: B
options.text: John Rawls

options.label: C
options.text: Karl Marx

options.label: D
options.text: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

multiple-choice.question: According to John Rawls, what is the primary goal of the thought experiment "the original position"?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the most efficient economic system

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the most just society for all citizens

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a new form of government

options.label: D
options.text: To promote individual freedom and autonomy

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of John Rawls' 1971 book that introduced the concept of "the original position"?

options.label: A
options.text: "A Theory of Justice"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Social Contract"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Wealth of Nations"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Communist Manifesto"

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the idea that people in the thought experiment are unaware of their own characteristics, such as age, sex, and wealth?

options.label: A
options.text: The veil of ignorance

options.label: B
options.text: The social contract

options.label: C
options.text: The original position

options.label: D
options.text: The difference principle

multiple-choice.question: According to Rawls, what is the primary good that should be distributed equally among citizens in a just society?

options.label: A
options.text: Wealth

options.label: B
options.text: Liberty

options.label: C
options.text: Opportunity

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the idea that wealth inequalities are only acceptable if they benefit the least advantaged citizens?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference principle

options.label: B
options.text: The veil of ignorance

options.label: C
options.text: The original position

options.label: D
options.text: The social contract

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the model of democracy proposed by John Rawls, which guarantees equal access to education and healthcare and relies on government regulation to ensure a just distribution of property and wealth?

options.label: A
options.text: Property owning democracy

options.label: B
options.text: Social democracy

options.label: C
options.text: Democratic socialism

options.label: D
options.text: Liberal democracy

multiple-choice.question: According to Ronald Dworkin, what is the problem with the difference principle?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not take into account the needs of the worst-off

options.label: B
options.text: It unfairly tethers society's progress to the status of the worst-off

options.label: C
options.text: It does not promote individual freedom and autonomy

options.label: D
options.text: It does not prioritize economic efficiency

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the idea that the thought experiment "the original position" overlooks real-life particulars, such as the special needs of individuals with disabilities?

options.label: A
options.text: The social contract

options.label: B
options.text: The original position

options.label: C
options.text: The difference principle

options.label: D
options.text: The critique of Rawls' thought experiment

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of John Rawls' thought experiment on contemporary politics and philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: It has had no significant impact

options.label: B
options.text: It has inspired a new school of thought about justice

options.label: C
options.text: It has led to the development of new economic systems

options.label: D
options.text: It has promoted individual freedom and autonomy

title: The Nazis recruited to win the Cold War - Brian Crim

multiple-choice.question: Who was the high-ranking Nazi engineer who approached the US government directly after Adolf Hitler's death?

options.label: A
options.text: Hermann Göring

options.label: B
options.text: Joseph Goebbels

options.label: C
options.text: Wernher von Braun

options.label: D
options.text: Heinrich Himmler

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the clandestine campaign that brought over 1,500 German scientists to the US between 1945 and 1962?

options.label: A
options.text: Operation Overlord

options.label: B
options.text: Operation Paperclip

options.label: C
options.text: Operation Barbarossa

options.label: D
options.text: Operation Torch

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the primary reason for the US government's interest in recruiting German scientists after World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent the Soviet Union from acquiring their expertise

options.label: B
options.text: To compensate for the loss of American scientists during the war

options.label: C
options.text: To provide employment opportunities for German scientists

options.label: D
options.text: To gather intelligence on the Soviet Union

multiple-choice.question: Who was one of the prominent voices that opposed granting German scientists citizenship, alongside Albert Einstein and Eleanor Roosevelt?

options.label: A
options.text: NAACP

options.label: B
options.text: American Civil Liberties Union

options.label: C
options.text: Veteran's organizations

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the rocket that brought Americans to the moon, designed by Wernher von Braun and his team?

options.label: A
options.text: Saturn V

options.label: B
options.text: Apollo 11

options.label: C
options.text: Mercury 7

options.label: D
options.text: Gemini 12

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was one of the reasons why the US military was able to justify keeping former Nazis in sensitive national security positions despite popular objections?

options.label: A
options.text: The Cold War had made the threat of communism more pressing

options.label: B
options.text: The US government had promised to relocate entire German families and grant them citizenship

options.label: C
options.text: The Soviet Union was also employing former Nazis in their own military

options.label: D
options.text: The US military had evidence that the former Nazis were not guilty of war crimes

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the chemical weapon that was developed with the help of Paperclip recruits?

options.label: A
options.text: Agent Orange

options.label: B
options.text: Mustard gas

options.label: C
options.text: Sarin

options.label: D
options.text: VX

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the questions raised by the contentious approach to science, ethics, and national security in the context of Operation Paperclip?

options.label: A
options.text: Can scientists working on military technology be apolitical?

options.label: B
options.text: Can pressing political and military concerns justify overlooking war crimes?

options.label: C
options.text: Can the US government justify employing former Nazis in sensitive national security positions?

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote the obituary that sums up the operation's murkiness, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Wernher von Braun

options.label: B
options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: C
options.text: Eleanor Roosevelt

options.label: D
options.text: The author of the transcript

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase used to describe the "fascinating career" of Wernher von Braun, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A Faustian bargain

options.label: B
options.text: A Faustian shadow

options.label: C
options.text: A Faustian pact

options.label: D
options.text: A Faustian deal

title: How to prevent political corruption - Stephanie Honchell Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of corruption, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A misuse of power for personal gain

options.label: B
options.text: A misuse of power for public good

options.label: C
options.text: A misuse of power for economic growth

options.label: D
options.text: A misuse of power for social justice

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the offer made to Mcebisi Jonas by the Gupta brothers?

options.label: A
options.text: A promotion and $45 million

options.label: B
options.text: A promotion and $50 million

options.label: C
options.text: A demotion and $45 million

options.label: D
options.text: A promotion and $40 million

multiple-choice.question: What type of corruption was practiced by the Alcmaeonid family in ancient Greece?

options.label: A
options.text: Bribing the priestesses at Delphi to deliver false prophecies

options.label: B
options.text: Bribing the politicians to pass laws

options.label: C
options.text: Bribing the citizens to vote for them

options.label: D
options.text: Bribing the judges to make favorable decisions

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if anti-corruption laws aren't enforced, or if loopholes are continuously exploited?

options.label: A
options.text: A larger culture of corruption can emerge

options.label: B
options.text: A smaller culture of corruption can emerge

options.label: C
options.text: No culture of corruption can emerge

options.label: D
options.text: A culture of transparency can emerge

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of corruption that is not directly about money, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The Gupta family plundering billions of dollars from South Africa's funds

options.label: B
options.text: The Baltimore Police Department's widespread patterns of unconstitutional policing, abuse, and corruption

options.label: C
options.text: The Alcmaeonid family bribing the priestesses at Delphi

options.label: D
options.text: The British MPs using taxpayer money to cover personal expenses

multiple-choice.question: What can we do to prevent corruption, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Only punish those who engage in corruption

options.label: B
options.text: Only increase transparency in terms of budget and paper trails

options.label: C
options.text: Both punish those who engage in corruption and increase transparency

options.label: D
options.text: Neither punish those who engage in corruption nor increase transparency

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a country that has built public trust through their ongoing commitment to respond to corruption openly, quickly, and decisively?

options.label: A
options.text: South Africa

options.label: B
options.text: Botswana

options.label: C
options.text: Denmark

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if we don't stand up against corruption when we see it, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Corruption will decrease

options.label: B
options.text: Corruption will remain the same

options.label: C
options.text: Corruption will increase

options.label: D
options.text: It will have no effect on corruption

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how corruption can snowball, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: If anti-corruption laws aren't enforced, or if loopholes are continuously exploited

options.label: B
options.text: If corruption is punished severely

options.label: C
options.text: If corruption is ignored

options.label: D
options.text: If corruption is encouraged

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to use our civic voices to fight back against corruption, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: So that tax dollars can line the pockets of corrupt officials

options.label: B
options.text: So that tax dollars can benefit everyone

options.label: C
options.text: So that corruption can increase

options.label: D
options.text: So that corruption can remain the same
